result.short_description: Deliver apps to your employees or customers using a modern, easy to use portal
result.author: ServiceNow

result.additional_uses: General approvals • Any simple approval process • Request management
result.author: ServiceNow
result.how_was_built:
How we built this

1. Planned and defined desired outcomes
Before we started building this application, we defined its key use cases and what we
wanted out of this application. We also mapped out the required user roles, the process
map, and the data model. To further define the app, we also wireframed the user
experience and identified the notification templates needed.

2. Set up the application
To create this application, we decided on a name and a description.

3. Added data
We uploaded a spreadsheet with table definitions and sample records to create a table.

4. Added roles
We created 3 roles: employee, manager, and admin. We also added permissions to the
table.

5. Added experiences
Using UI Builder, we created a web interface for employees to make requests and
added the ability for manager to view requests. We also built a dashboard for
managers. With this dashboard, managers are able to review all requests from
employees and their team, helping them make informed decisions.

6. Added automation
Using Flow Designer, we defined the trigger and actions needed to create our approval
workflow and email notifications.

7. Tested the application before submitting for review
After adding everything necessary for this app, we ran a test and previewed it to make
sure it worked and matched our desired use cases and outcomes. After approval, we
turned this into a template

Learn how to use this template to create an app

How to make your app more powerful:

· Allow delegates (“Submit on behalf”, “Secondary approver”, “Approver during manager time off”)

· Integrate with Outlook Calendar or other scheduling app

· Include scheduling validations (hours per week or month worked, vacation taken per year)

· Add Shift Management options: shifts table, # employees per shift, replacement list

· Integrate with time clock or payroll applications
result.detailed_description: This app helps streamline and simplify the process of tracking time off requests and approvals.

result.how_was_built:
How we built this

1. Planned and defined desired outcomes
Before we started building this application, we defined its key use cases and what we wanted out of this application. We also mapped out the required user roles, the process map, and the data model. To further define the app, we also wireframed the user experience.

2. Set up the application
To create this application, we decided on a name and a description.

3. Added data
We created the notes table and referenced the sys_user table.

4. Added roles
We added 2 roles: employee and admin. Permissions for these were added to the table.

5. Added mobile applet experiences
We created employee directory, map, and custom table mobile applets.

6. Added automation
Using Flow Designer, we defined the trigger and actions needed to create custom notifications.

7. Tested the application before submitting for review
After adding everything necessary for this app, we ran a test and previewed it to make sure it worked and matched our desired use cases and outcomes. After approval, we turned this into a template.

Learn how to use this template to create an app


How to make your app more powerful

After using this template to create an app, you can add additional features to better fit your needs.
  • Add integration with Google Directory Model
  • Add integration with other data sources (gmail, outlook, etc)
  • Allow employees to create non-employee contacts
  • Add employee shift and vacation information
  • Add NLU search integration (e.g. Google voice)
  • Add other tags than "favorite"

result.short_description: Schedule and manage employee performance reviews
result.additional_uses: Document submission · Annual Compliance · Regular review process · Deadline management
result.author: ServiceNow
result.how_was_built:
How we built this

1. Planned and defined desired outcomes
Before we started building this application, we defined its key use cases and what we wanted out of this application. We also mapped out the required user roles, the process map, and the data model. To further define the app, we also wireframed the user experience.

2. Set up the application
To create this application, we decided on a name and a description.

3. Added data
We uploaded a spreadsheet to create a self-evaluation table.

4. Added two experiences
First, we created a portal interface for employees to submit self-evaluations. Next, we created a workspace interface for managers to monitor this activity using a dashboard. We used UI Builder to further build out this workspace.

5. Added automation
After setting up an automated workflow, we used Flow Designer to set up the triggers, actions, and conditions. This set up 3 review schedules to send out email notifications.

6.  Added security
We created 3 user roles: employee, manager, admin. We also set up access controls and permissions for the app.

7. Tested the application before submitting for review
After adding everything necessary for this app, we ran a test and previewed it to make sure it worked and matched our desired use cases and outcomes. After approval, we turned this into a template.

Learn how to use this template to create an app

How to make your app more powerful

After using this template to create an app, you can add additional features to better fit your needs. Add continuous option as a review process 

  • Use Playbook to manage review schedules
  • Include HR review and escalation process for both self-reviews and manager reviews
  • Add peer reviews process
  • Add goal setting or OKRs
  • Add integration with HR software
  • Add skill set assessment metrics
  • Add PIP process and individual development plans
  • Include compensation info or APR
result.detailed_description: This app helps automate the process of scheduling annual or quarterly reviews, reviewing employee performance, and providing manager feedback.

result.how_was_built:
How we built this

1. Planned and defined desired outcomes
Before we started building this application, we defined its key use cases and what we wanted out of this application. We also mapped out the required user roles, the process map, and the data model. To further define the app, we also wireframed the user experience.

2. Set up the application
To create this application, we decided on a name and a description.

3. Added data
We created all the data tables, starting with the status matrix. The status matrix is referenced by the self-reporting table.

4. Added roles
We created 3 roles: employees, managers, admins. We also added permissions to the tables.

5. Added experiences
Using UI Builder, we created a web interface for employees to self-report, and workspace with a dashboard for managers to monitor teams and review requests.

6. Added automation
Using FlowDesigner, we defined the trigger and actions to create our approval workflow and email notifications.

7. Tested the application before submitting for review
After adding everything necessary for this app, we ran a test and previewed it to make sure it worked and matched our desired use cases and outcomes. After approval, we turned this into a template.

Learn how to use this template to create an app.


How to make your app more powerful
  • Version control & ability to upload newversions
  • Automate post submission – send to SharePoint, email to finance, etc.
  • Drag and drop – uploadfeature
result.detailed_description: This app creates workflows for approving documents. Customize this template to create documents and add approvers, who are then notified to either approve or reject the documents. Each approval workflow can have multiple stages and multiple approvers.

result.short_description: Accelerate reporting and communications during an emergency
result.additional_uses: Time off requests with simple approvals    •    Status reports and updates   •    Family Gatherings    •    Appointment requests
result.author: ServiceNow
result.how_was_built:
How we build this

1. Planned and defined desired outcomes

Before we start building, we defined the desired outcomes and key use cases of this app. As a team, we mapped out the required user roles, the process map and the data model. We also wireframed the user experience.

2. Set up the application

Now we are ready to start. First, we created an application by naming it and adding a description.

3. Added data

We are now ready to move to the Data step. We created all the data tables, starting with the status matrix, since that is referenced by the self-reporting table.

4. Added roles

Next, we created 3 user roles – employees, managers, admins – and added permissions to the tables.

5. Added mobile applet experiences

Now we move to the Experience step. We created a web interface for employees to self-report, and workspace with dashboard for managers to monitor teams and approve/reject, using UI Builder.

6. Added automation

Next, we head to the Automation Step. Using Flow Designer, we defined the trigger and actions needed to create our approval workflow and email notifications.

7. Tested the application before submitting for review

With everything created, we ran a test to make sure the app works.

After completing the steps above, you should be ready to submit your app!

Learn how to use this template to create an app


How to make your app more powerful

  • Translate employees’ responses to English using IBM Watson spoke
  • Build an automated workflow to post a message into a Slack channel with a Zoom link if an employee response indicates a positive test for Covid-19
  • Emergency State model with custom workflows per emergency organized using the Process Automation Designer
  • Integrate Time-Off requests with HR workflows or systems
  • Virtual agent
result.detailed_description: This app helps organizations keep everyone informed and connected during natural disasters and pandemics like COVID-19.
